descriptions:

Title: The Future of Prediction: The Social Consequences of Algorithmic Forecast in Insurance, Medicine, and Policing

This project investigates the far-reaching social implications of the shift from probabilistic to algorithmic forms of prediction in three critical domains: insurance, medicine, and policing. As Big Data and Machine Learning technologies increasingly enable personalized forecasting, we must critically examine the consequences of this transition on social institutions and the individuals they serve. The project focuses on the challenges posed by individualized prediction, including the undermining of the mutualization principle, the need to combine algorithmic and statistical methods, and the problem of bias in predictive models. Through a multidisciplinary approach, this research will explore the intersection of digital forecasting, uncertainty management, and probability calculus in personalized insurance, precision medicine, and predictive policing. By elucidating the social consequences of algorithmic prediction, this project aims to inform policy and practice, ensuring that the benefits of these technologies are equitably distributed and their risks are mitigated.

Title: The Future of Prediction: The Social Consequences of Algorithmic Forecast in Insurance, Medicine, and Policing

This interdisciplinary research project investigates the far-reaching social consequences of the transition from probabilistic to algorithmic forms of prediction in three critical domains: insurance, medicine, and policing. The proliferation of Big Data and Machine Learning has enabled the development of digital forecasting tools that promise unprecedented accuracy and efficiency. However, these advances also raise crucial questions about the individualization of prediction, the undermining of mutualization principles, and the combination of algorithmic and statistical methods. Furthermore, concerns about bias and the distinction between prevention and repression in predictive policing require urgent attention. This project will explore the implications of algorithmic prediction for personalized insurance, precision medicine, and predictive policing, with a focus on uncertainty management and probability calculus. By examining the social consequences of algorithmic forecasting, this research aims to provide critical insights into the impact of technological innovation on social institutions and to inform evidence-based policy decisions that balance the benefits of prediction with the need to protect individual and collective rights.
